data.title: Boris Chertok
data.meta_description: In the late 1950s and early 1960s, in the days before the creation of America’s National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa), when the Soviet Union appeared to have an unassailable lead in
data.text:
In the late 1950s and early 1960s, in the days before the creation of America’s National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa), when the Soviet Union appeared to have an unassailable lead in rocketry and space flight, American scientists and military men could only look on in despair as its great — and furthermore socialist — competitor on the geopolitical stage, surged ahead with a number of resounding firsts: first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth (1957) and first man in space (1961).

As Sputnik 1 and then Major Yuri Gagarin in Vostok 1 successively mocked America’s best efforts, while a series of US Army and Navy rockets blew up with infuriating regularity on their launch pads, one man in particular became the bane of America’s
